text: I’m trying to register a package but there are missing compat entries in Project.toml. Shouldn’t those (or at least some kind of template for them) be created when I `Pkg.add` the dependencies in the package’s environment?

elements.text: I’m trying to register a package but there are missing compat entries in Project.toml. Shouldn’t those (or at least some kind of template for them) be created when I
the dependencies in the package’s environment?

text: Or is there a way to just say “fill the compat entries with the current versions of the packages that are installed, since I know they are working”?

elements.text: Or is there a way to just say “fill the compat entries with the current versions of the packages that are installed, since I know they are working”?

text: CompatHelper can do this, but I agree that it should be added automatically by Pkg

elements.text: CompatHelper can do this, but I agree that it should be added automatically by Pkg

text: CompatHelper seems to do one package at a time

elements.text: CompatHelper seems to do one package at a time

text: Yeah that's correct, you can check the readme to see if there's an option to do multiple but I don’t think so

elements.text: Yeah that's correct, you can check the readme to see if there's an option to do multiple but I don’t think so

text: This is exactly what I wrote `PackageCompatUI` for. See the announcement: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/ann-packagecompatui/58118>

attachments.title: [ANN] PackageCompatUI
attachments.text: PackageCompatUI is a terminal text interface to the [compat] section of a Julia Project.toml file. This is particularly useful when setting up [compat] for a new package or if you need unusual [compat] bounds but is uncertain about the syntax to use. To keep up to date with breaking versions of dependencies, CompatHelper is the canonical tool. Installation Julia 1.6 is required. Use the REPL Pkg mode as usual for a registered package or using Pkg Pkg.add("PackageCompatUI") Add it to your de...

elements.text: This is exactly what I wrote

text: <@UBVE598BC>: Great! Can it automatically just choose the installed versions? I have no idea which other versions are compatible with my new package (and no interest in finding out…)
